FacilityName: Naval Air Weapons Station China Lake, CA

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Shore Station Management, under the Chief of Navy Installations (CNI), embodies the personnel of NAWS China Lake. The installation's commanding officer is responsible for the physical infrastructure of the entire facility; buildings, grounds, roads, utilities, physical security, and all elements related to its maintenance, upkeep, repair, and improvements.

The Supply Department performs the functions of; receiving, issuing, shipping, delivery, storage, inventory management, stock control, and personal property. It provides the support for all station activities and intermediate levels of aircraft maintenance. It receives, stores, issues, and delivers aviation fuels, liquid oxygen, and liquid nitrogen for aircraft operations.

The Safety and Physical Security Department provides fire fighting, law enforcement, physical security, and occupational health and safety services. The Fire Division provides fire suppression, fire prevention, rescue, ambulance and emergency management services. The Police (Physical Security) Division provides law/traffic enforcement, vehicle mishap investigation, visitor control, pass and identification, and security alarm services. The Safety Office implements the Navy Occupational Safety and Health (NAVOSH) program, Explosive Safety Program, and the Hazardous Materials Control and Management Program.

The Environmental Planning and Management Department provides; environmental compliance; natural resource conservation, protection, and monitoring; cultural resource conservation, protection, and monitoring; hazardous waste operations and emergency response; and pollution prevention services.

GENERAL STATEMENT

 NAWS China Lake is located approximately 150 miles northeast of Los Angeles, CA. The land varies in altitude from 2,100 to 8,900 feet with a landmass of some 1,754 square miles. Additionally, the controlled airspace encompasses over 17,000 square miles.

NAWS China Lake is accessible via three state highways; 14, 178, and 395. The st

ation is bordered by the City of Ridgecrest on its south and Inyokern on its west boundaries. To the east lies the town of Trona and the north and east boundaries of NAWS China Lake are bordered by Wilderness Areas of the Bureau of Land Management (BLM). Except for the BLM lands, land use around NAWS China Lake is residential, and commercial. NAWS China Lake lies in three counties; Inyo, Kern, and San Bernardino. 

The Navy has stewardship of approximately 34,700 acres in Kern County, 537,000 acres in Inyo County, and 527,000 acres in San Bernardino County. The Kern County acreage encompasses about 3% of the NAWS controlled properties in the Indian Wells Valley.  The Main site area is contiguous with the City of Ridgecrest, CA. 

There are 919 people, military and their families, residing in the NAWS Main Site area. During the workweek there are 4508 employees coming aboard to work in the Kern County portion of the NAWS China Lake. An additional 1400 civilians come aboard each day during the workweek to attend elementary, middle school, and to attend day care. The total number of employees that work in Inyo County during the workweek fluctuates with a maximum number of 180. The daily average during the workweek is 110 employees including contract personnel. These numbers do not include employees of Coso Operating Company LLC, working at the Coso Geothermal Plant. Coso Operating Company LLC is responsible for all Coso Geothermal Plant operations. During the workweek approximately 775 employees work in the San Bernardino County portion of the NAWS China Lake. 

There are numerous sites where unexploded ordnance may be encountered in all three counties. Range operations procedures mandate that personnel working on the ranges be accounted for daily.

There are several research laboratories located in the Main Site area. Their focus is on weapons development and weapons systems engineering support.  NAWS China Lake is not a mass producer of any product. There are many re

search laboratories in the Salt Wells area in San Bernardino County. The operations conducted in the Salt Wells area are focused on the development of various explosives and propellants. There are no research laboratories located within Inyo County. There are no schools located within 1000 feet of any research laboratories that use and store hazardous materials. There are no schools, hospital, or extended care facilities within 1000 feet (straight line distance) of any facility within either Inyo or San Bernardino Counties.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY

NAWS China Lake is committed to operating and maintaining all its processes, especially those using hazardous materials, in a safe and responsible manner. NAWS China Lake uses a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees, the public, and the protection of the environment. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented. They are as follows:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by the EPA's RMP regulation.
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases.
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs.
* A 5-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule.
* An overview of our emergency response program.
* An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment.
* The certifications that EPA's RMP rule requires us to provide.
* The detailed information (data elements) of our Risk Management Program Plan.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In the event of an emergency involving the release or threate

ned release of chlorine gas, from the chlorine gas storage facility, the NAWS China Lake Fire Division will be notified by telephone by dialing "911", by the alarm pulls or the automatic sensor trip that will sound the alarm causing personnel evacuation and notifying the Fire Division. The Fire Division conducts unannounced periodic drills on the evacuation process. The NAWS China Lake emergency plan provides direction on chain-of-command and action coordination for any significant emergency situation

The Fire Division notifies the spill response crew. The spill response crew is issued beepers and two-way radios for immediate notification.

RMP STAIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

NAWS China Lake has one (1) process exceeding the threshold for chlorine gas used for wastewater treatment. The chlorine storage facility is located in a restricted area northeast of the Main Site in Kern County. The facility is of brick and mortar construction with a corrugated galvanized steel roof.  The facility has proper lighting providing good illumination within. The facility has 3 personnel doors and a large roll up door through which chlorine gas deliveries are made. The facility has a large shuttered ventilation opening at the end opposite the large roll up door. The opening is screened over to prevent birds and other indigenous wildlife from entering the facility. The facility is heated during the winter months and cooled during the summer months. There is a single deep sink in the facility used for hand washing after maintenance tasks. The facility has two (2) internal atmosphere monitoring ports, one located at each end of the facility. The monitoring system has preset alarm levels that upon being triggered sound the alarm within the facility and sends an alarm signal to the NAWS China Lake Fire Division.  Additionally there are manual alarm push button switches. The facility has a windsock installed to indicate wind direction in case of a release. At capacity the waste

water treatment system facility contains 3704 pounds of chlorine gas on line.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There has been a single minor accidental release in the past 5 years. The accidental release occurred on 30 August 2002. A faulty fitting caused the minor release.  The fitting was promptly replaced and the system put back into operation. The released chlorine gas was approximately 1 pound, well below the reporting threshold of 10 pounds, and caused no injuries and had no impact on any environmental resources.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

NAWS China Lake represents a complete functioning community with its own fire, police, medical, explosive ordnance disposal, analytic chemistry, and public works support divisions. Under any emergency condition all equipment and support personnel are immediately available. Prominent notices delineating all emergency assistance information are posted in all buildings and work areas.

NAWS China Lake has its own Fire Division that operates from three (3) different fire stations on base. All buildings on base have the OSHA required type and number of fire extinguishers. All fire extinguishers and other pieces of emergency equipment are monitored, tested, and maintained by the OSH office and the Fire Division. 

NAWS China Lake personnel are responsible for all spill and disaster management actions on base. If an emergency situation arises at NAWS China Lake the Fire Division and Branch Medical Clinic will assist in providing emergency transportation of victims of the disaster to the Ridgecrest Regional Hospital and/or other critical care facilities.

Certified hazardous waste removal and a transportation company are on contract for situations beyond the ability of our spill response crew.

NAWS China Lake works closely with the Indian Wells Valley Emergency Services Committee, which is headed by the City Manager for the City of Ridgecrest, CA.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES

AGENCY NOTIFICATION: Personnel working in the Wastewat

er Chlorine Storage Facility are required to immediately report, from a safe location, any release or threatened release of chlorine gas to the following:

1. NAWS China Lake Fire Division by dialing "911" or by depressing the manual alarm push button switches thereby signaling the Fire Division of an emergency situation. At the first opportunity, either the Fire Division or the personnel involved with the chlorine facility shall notify the EPMD Office of the situation at 939-2750 or 939-2167.

NAWS China Lake Fire Division responders shall assess the situation in full personal protective gear including Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA). All other personnel on scene are to remain in a safe location until the Fire Division has secured the situation.

If further reporting is required, personnel from the EPMD will, by direction of the NAWS China Lake Commanding Officer, notify one or more of the following agencies:

2. NAWS China Lake Emergency Management Officer

Emergency Information Required When Reporting a Release (FROM A SAFE VANTAGE POINT):
* Name of person reporting and phone number
* Name and building number of Navy organizational element
* Location of the incident or threatened release
* Type of incident (spill, gas release, threatened release, etc.)
* Hazardous material involved (chemical name or ID of substance and physical state (solid, liquid, gas)
* Environmental media to which the release occurred (soil, water, air, etc.)
* Estimate of the quantity of hazardous material(s) involved
* Is the chemical an Extremely Hazardous Substance as listed in SARA Title III, Section 302
* Time and duration of the release
* Precautions t

o take (if known)
* Possible hazards to human health/and or the environment
* Extent of injures, if any
* Methods taken to cleanup/recover hazardous materials
* Estimated quantity and disposition of any recovered materials 
 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPPOVE SAFETY

PREVENTION: Personnel working in the Wastewater Chlorine Storage Facility are required to make sure that valves are closed, doors are locked, caps are replaced, and that regular maintenance is completed. The Safety and Industrial Hygiene offices perform routine inspections and identified problem areas are cited for immediate correction. 

MITIGATION: Efforts are under way to reduce the amount of hazardous materials being used. The storage of smaller quantities of material will lessen the chance of a significant incident.

ABATEMENT: In an emergency situation the Fire Division is immediately notified either by telephone or the alarm system. The incident is then assessed for hazardous consequences. Either the spill cleanup crew or the Emergency Response Team is notified and the proper regulatory agencies are contacted. The incident is then remediated in accordance with all federal, state, and local regulations.

TRAINING: NAWS China Lake training is provided by various organizational elements. The OSH office provides Hazard Communication training including specific hazard training via the Chief of Navy Installations web site. The Environmental Planning and Management Department provides initial HAZWOPER and annual refresher training. The Fire Division provides training on Disaster Preparedness as well as the proper use of fire extinguishers. Additionally, each organizational element provides Safety training on topics specific to their operations. Training records are maintained for three (3) years at the OSH office.

ALTERNATIVE TECHNOLOGIES/PROCESSES: NAWS China Lake performed a feasibility study on changing from chlorine gas for its wastewater treatment to a concentrated solution of sodium hypochlorite. The st

udy determined that the change of process chemistry involved much more than a simple "drop-in" replacement. Aside from the Hypochlorite solution, other supporting chemicals had to be used. The change would have additionally required major construction to our facility and the procurement and installation of additional reaction vessels. This would have necessitated the initiation of a Military Construction (MILCON) request. If granted the MILCON would, in and of itself, have been cost prohibitive without factoring in the additional cost of the reaction vessels, addition chemicals, and increased manpower to operate the new process. For these reasons the change was deemed not feasible at this time. NAWS China Lake continues to watch for alternative technologies and processes for its wastewater treatment system.
